content.description: An object of mass <math alttext="4 kilograms " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> initially at rest on a surface has both kinetic and potential energies equal to zero. It is then lifted under the influence of both nonconservative forces and the conservative force of gravity. The nonconservative forces do <math alttext="positive 40 joules " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>40</mn><mtext> J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of work on the object. The conservative force does <math alttext="negative 22 joules " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>22</mn><mtext> J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of work.
